Identification.LongTitle: Maritime Occupational Health and Safety Regulations

Provision.Text: Her Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of Labour and the Minister of Transport, pursuant to section 157a of the Canada Labour Codeb, hereby makes the annexed Maritime Occupational Health and Safety Regulations.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in these Regulations.

Definition.Text: Act means Part II of the Canada Labour Code. (Loi)
ANSI means the American National Standards Institute. (ANSI)

approved organization means an organization that is approved by any province for the teaching of first aid, or a recognized institution within the meaning of subsection 1(1) of the Marine Personnel Regulations. (organisme agréé)
confined space means an enclosed or partially enclosed space that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is not designed or intended for human occupancy, except for the purpose of performing work;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has restricted means of access and egress; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: may become hazardous to any person entering it owing to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: its design, construction, location or atmosphere,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the materials or substances in it, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: any other conditions relating to it. (espace clos)

Definition.Text: crew accommodation means living, eating, recreational or sleeping quarters provided by an employer for the accommodation of employees on a vessel. (logement de l’équipage)
CSA means the Canadian Standards Association. (CSA)
day vessel means a vessel that is not equipped with adequate accommodation to provide rest for employees. (bâtiment de jour)
disabling injury means an employment injury or an occupational disease that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prevents an employee from reporting for work or from effectively performing all the duties connected with their regular work on any day after the day on which the injury or disease occurred, whether or not that later day was a work day for that employee;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: results in an employee’s loss of a body member or part of one or in the complete loss of the usefulness of a body member or part of one; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: results in the permanent impairment of a body function of an employee. (blessure invalidante)

Definition.Text: electrical equipment means equipment for the generation, distribution or use of electricity. (outillage électrique)
first aid certificate means the certificate issued by or with the authority of an approved organization for successful completion of a two-day first aid course. (certificat de secourisme)

gross tonnage means the volume of a vessel as determined by a tonnage measurer or calculated in accordance with the regulations made under paragraph 77(h) of the Canada Shipping Act, 2001. (jauge brute)
ILO means the International Labour Organization. (OIT)
IMO means the International Maritime Organization. (OMI)

inland voyage means a voyage on the inland waters of Canada together with any part of any lake or river forming part of the inland waters of Canada that lies within the United States or a voyage on Lake Michigan. (voyage en eaux internes)
inland waters of Canada means all the rivers, lakes and other navigable fresh waters within Canada, and includes the St. Lawrence River as far seawards as a straight line drawn

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: from Cap-des-Rosiers to West Point, Anticosti Island; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: from Anticosti Island to the north shore of the St. Lawrence River along the meridian of longitude 63°W. (eaux internes du Canada)

Definition.Text: international voyage means a voyage between a place in Canada and a place not in Canada or between places not in Canada. (voyage international)
isolation means separation or disconnection from every source of energy that is capable of making equipment dangerous. (isolation)

lock out means placement of a lock on equipment, machines or energy-isolating devices in accordance with an established procedure, to indicate that the equipment, machines or devices are not to be operated until the lock is removed in accordance with an established procedure. (cadenasser)
marine chemist means a qualified person who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is a graduate of a post-secondary education institution who

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: has successfully completed courses in chemical engineering,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: has successfully completed a general program with a major in chemistry, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: is a member of the Chemical Institute of Canada; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has at least three years experience in chemical or engineering work, after the person has satisfied the requirements of paragraph (a), of which a minimum of 150 working hours were spent under proper supervision in work on board a vessel involving the testing of tank reservoirs and other containers in the application of gas hazard control standards. (chimiste de la marine)

Definition.Text: MLC 2006 means the Maritime Labour Convention, 2006. (CTM 2006)
near coastal voyage, Class 1 has the same meaning as in section 1 of the Vessel Certificates Regulations. (voyage à proximité du littoral, classe 1)
NIOSH means the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health in the United States. (NIOSH)

oxygen-deficient atmosphere means an atmosphere in which there is less than 19.5 per cent by volume of oxygen at a pressure of one atmosphere or in which the partial pressure of oxygen is less than 148 mm Hg. (air à faible teneur en oxygène)
passenger vessel means a passenger ship as defined in Regulations 2(e) and (f), Part I, chapter I of SOLAS. (bâtiment à passagers)
personal service room means a change room, sanitary facility, shower room, or other area of the crew accommodation or a combination of those areas. (local réservé aux soins personnels)
protection equipment means safety materials, equipment, devices and clothing. (équipement de protection)
qualified person means, in respect of a specified duty, a person who, because of their knowledge, training and experience, is qualified to perform that duty safely and properly. (personne qualifiée)
rest means a period during which an employee is not assigned any duty and has access to sleeping quarters and sanitary facilities. (repos)
sanitary facility means a room that contains a water closet or a urinal. (cabinet de toilette)
SOLAS means the 2004 consolidated edition of the International Convention for Safety of Life at Sea, 1974. (SOLAS)

special purpose vessel means a vessel of not less than 500 gross tonnage that carries more than 12 special personnel who are needed for the particular operational duties of the vessel and are, in addition to those persons required for the normal navigation, engineering and maintenance of the vessel, engaged to provide services for the persons carried on board. (bâtiment spécial)
unlimited voyage has the same meaning as in section 1 of the Vessel Certificates Regulations. (voyage illimité)

ventilation equipment means a fan, blower, induced draft or other ventilation device used to force a supply of fresh, respirable atmospheric air into an enclosed space or to move ambient air from that space. (matérial de ventilation)
vessel has the same meaning as in section 2 of the Canada Shipping Act, 2001. (bâtiment)

Section.Text: For the purpose of interpreting any standard incorporated by reference into these Regulations, the use of “should” is to be read as denoting an obligation.

These Regulations apply to any person who is not an employee but who performs for an employer to which these Regulations apply activities whose primary purpose is to enable the person to acquire knowledge or experience, and to the employer, as if that person were an employee of the employer, and every provision of these Regulations must be read accordingly.
These Regulations apply to employees employed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on vessels registered in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on uncommissioned vessels of Her Majesty in right of Canada; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the loading or unloading of vessels.

Subsection.Text: If an employer is required to keep and maintain a record, report or other document referred to in section 125 or 125.1 of the Act, the employer must keep and maintain the record, report or other document and make it readily available for examination by the Minister, the work place committee or the health and safety representative, as the case may be, and the policy committee, if one exists, for the vessel to which it applies.
To comply with subsection (1), the employer may use any recording system, including electronic records, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: measures are taken to ensure that the records contained in the recording systems are protected, by electronic or other means, against inadvertent loss or destruction and against tampering; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the records contained in the recording systems can be printed on paper and provided on reasonable notice at the request of the Minister.

Section.Text: In the event of an inconsistency between any standard incorporated by reference in these Regulations and any other provision of these Regulations, that other provision must prevail to the extent of the inconsistency.
Any reference to a standard incorporated by reference in these Regulations is a reference to the standard, as amended from time to time.

Subsection.Text: Every employer must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: arrange that work in a working area is carried out in a manner that does not endanger the health or safety of any person who is engaged or working in that area or in connection with the work; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: adopt and carry out appropriate procedures and techniques designed or intended to prevent or reduce the risk of employment injury in the operation or carrying out of the work.

Subsection.Text: Crew accommodation must meet the requirements and the related provisions on health and safety protection and accident prevention, with respect to preventing the risk of exposure to hazardous levels of noise and vibration and other ambient factors and chemicals on board vessels, and provide an acceptable occupational and on-board living environment for employees.
Every employer or owner must ensure that a qualified person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is in charge in every working area; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: inspects every working area or structure and every item of machinery or equipment to ascertain that safe working conditions are maintained.

Subsection.Text: A person must not use any structure, machinery or equipment that has been reassembled after being dismantled, in whole or in part, until it has been examined by a qualified person and found to be in a safe condition.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: accommodation ladder means a means of access to and egress from a vessel that may include platforms on different levels with ladders between the platforms and that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is suspended by a supporting structure of chains or steel wire ropes from its lowest suspension point;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is hinged at its top; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: can be moved so that the lowest platform is accessible from shore. (échelle de coupée)

Definition.Text: scaffold means a working platform supported from below. (échafaudage)
stage means a working platform supported from above. (plate-forme suspendue)

Section.Text: This Part applies to permanent and temporary structures, means of access, gangways, scaffolds, stages, ladders, guardrails, toe boards and safety nets.
The employer must ensure that the design and construction of every structure on a vessel meets the applicable requirements set out in one or more of the following regulations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Crew Accommodation Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Hull Construction Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Small Vessel Regulations; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: Towboat Crew Accommodation Regulations.

Subsection.Text: An employee must not use a temporary structure on a vessel if it is reasonably practicable to use a permanent structure.
An employee must not use a temporary structure unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: they have been trained and instructed in its safe and proper use; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: they have their employer’s authority to use it.

Subsection.Text: Tools, equipment and materials used on a temporary structure must be arranged or secured in a manner that they cannot be knocked off the structure accidentally.
A qualified person must make a visual inspection of the temporary structure before each work period in which a temporary structure is used by an employee.

When a temporary structure is used on a vessel and that structure may be affected by the ingress and egress of the tide, a qualified person must make a visual inspection of the structure at the end of each tide cycle.

If the inspection reveals a defect or condition that adversely affects the structural integrity or safe use of a temporary structure, a person must not use the structure until the defect or condition is remedied.
Means of access used to board and disembark from a vessel must provide a safe passage between the vessel and shore or between two vessels, as the case may be.
Every vessel that is moored alongside a wharf or another vessel must be fitted with at least one means of access between the vessel and the wharf or the other vessel.

If a means of access leads to a location on board a vessel that is more than 0.35 m above the deck, safe access to the deck must be provided by means of a series of steps, a ladder or other similar structure.
The series of steps, ladder or similar structure must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be firmly secured to the bulwark so as to prevent its shifting, slipping or pivoting;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be properly aligned with the means of access to the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: have treads that are at least 600 mm in width and 200 mm in depth, with a permanent non-slip surface; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with two handhold stanchions that are

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: not less than 40 mm in diameter,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: extended not less than 1.2 m above the top of the bulwark, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: fitted at the point of boarding or disembarking the vessel not less than 700 mm and not more than 800 mm apart.

Subsection.Text: Every accommodation ladder and gangway must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be maintained in a safe condition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be installed in a manner that reduces movement;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be suitably rigged and maintained to compensate for the movement of the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be adequately lighted;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: as far as practicable, be adjusted in such a way that, whatever the state of the tide or the draught of the ship, the accommodation ladder’s angle or the gangway’s angle to the horizontal plane is not more than 40°;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: be provided with a lifebuoy that has an attached line and is strategically placed and ready for immediate use; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements of one of the following standards:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: ISO Standard 5488:1979, Shipbuilding – Accommodation ladders,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: CSA Standard CAN/CSA-S826 SERIES-01 (R2006), Ferry Boarding Facilities,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the applicable standard of a classification society that has been furnished with a certificate by the Minister of Transport under subsection 12(2) of the Canada Shipping Act, 2001, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: if the ladder is part of pilot transfer equipment referred to in Regulation 23 of Chapter V of SOLAS, IMO Resolution A.889(21), Pilot Transfer Arrangements.

Subsection.Text: Paragraph 5(g) does not apply to accommodation ladders or gangways constructed prior to the coming into force of these Regulations.
Every means of access must be thoroughly examined by a qualified person at least once every year to ensure that the following conditions are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the loose gear used with it is in good working order;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the parts that align and swivel under load are free;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the mechanical, electrical, gearing, hydraulic and pneumatic systems are in good working order;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: parts are not affected by corrosion to the extent that they cannot be opened; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: no defects or signs of permanent deformation are detected.

Subsection.Text: If a means of access is being used by persons to board or disembark from a vessel, at least one end of it must be fastened securely and, if necessary to minimize its movement, an employee, other than an employee engaged in manoeuvring the vessel, must be stationed to assist the persons using it.
A safety net must be fitted under every part of a ladder, accommodation ladder or gangway, except if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the ladder or gangway and the approaches to it are constructed in a manner that makes the fitting of a safety net unnecessary; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the fitting of a safety net is not possible.

Subsection.Text: Every safety net referred to in subsection (9) must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: extend on both sides of the ladder, accommodation ladder or gangway for a distance of 1.8 m;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be kept taut at all times;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: as far as practicable, protect the entire length of the means of access; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: meet the standards referred to in section 17.

Subsection.Text: If a platform is provided at the bottom of a means of access, the platform must be flat and horizontal.
Unless otherwise permitted by this Part, a scaffold must meet the requirements set out in one or more of the following standards:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ANSI/ASSE Standard A10.8-2001, Scaffolding Safety Requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ANSI/ALI Standard A14.7-2006, American National Standard for Mobile Ladder Stands and Mobile Ladder Stand Platforms; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: CSA Standard CAN/CSA-Z271-98 (R2004), Safety Code for Suspended Elevating Platforms.

Subsection.Text: The erection, use, dismantling and removal of a scaffold must be carried out by or under the supervision of a qualified person.
If a scaffold is erected on an uneven surface, it must be provided with base plates that maintain its stability.
Every scaffold must be capable of supporting at least four times the load that is likely to be imposed on it.
Every scaffold must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have a platform that is at least 500 mm wide and securely fastened in place; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have a flat and horizontal working surface.

Subsection.Text: Every stage must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have a flat and horizontal working surface capable of supporting any load that is likely to be imposed on it; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be fitted with an effective means of holding the stage away from the working area.

Subsection.Text: The supporting structure and the ropes or tackle supporting a stage must have a safety factor of not less than six.
Commercially manufactured portable ladders must meet the requirements set out in one or more of the following standards:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: CSA Standard CAN3-Z11-M81 (R2005), Portable Ladders;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ANSI/ALI Standard A14.1 -2007, American National Standard for Ladders - Wood - Safety Requirements; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ANSI/ALI Standard A14.2 -2007, American National Standard for Ladders - Portable Metal - Safety Requirements.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), every portable ladder, while being used, must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: placed on a firm footing; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: secured in a manner that it cannot be dislodged accidentally from its position.

Subsection.Text: Every ladder, whether portable or permanently secured, must be positioned in a manner so that it is not necessary for a person to use the underside of the ladder.
If a ladder provides access from one level to another, the ladder must extend, if practicable, at least three rungs above the higher level or, if it is not practicable, handholds must be provided.
A metal or wire rope ladder must not be used if there is a hazard that it may come into contact with any live electrical circuit or electrical equipment.
An employee must not work from any of the three top rungs of any single or extension portable ladder or from either of the two top steps of any step ladder.
A non-metallic portable ladder must not be painted.

Every rope ladder must be of sufficient length to reach the intended landing point, unless the distance from the water to the point of access is more than 9 m, in which case a rope ladder is not to be used.
The means of attaching a rope ladder to a vessel must be effective and maintained in a safe condition.
A rope ladder must be equipped with flat wooden treads — at regular intervals with treads wider than the width of the ladder — and be installed in a manner that reduces movement of the ladder.
A rope ladder must not be used to provide access to places on shore except in case of emergency.
When it is necessary to ensure safety, a person must be stationed at the bottom of a ladder to assist the person using the ladder.
A raised structure or a deck opening that has a coaming height of less than 900 mm, from which there is a drop of more than 1.2 m, and to which an employee has access, must have a guardrail.
Every guardrail must consist of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a horizontal top rail or line not less than 900 mm and not more than 1100 mm above the base of the guardrail;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a horizontal intermediate rail or line spaced midway between the top rail or line and the base of the guardrail; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: supporting posts spaced not more than 3 m apart at their centres.

Subsection.Text: Every guardrail must be designed to withstand the greater of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the maximum load that is likely to be imposed on it, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a static load of not less than 890 N applied in any direction at any point on the top rail or line.

Subsection.Text: If there is hazard that tools or other objects may fall from a scaffold, a stage or any other raised structure onto a person, the employer must install

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a toe board that extends from the floor of the platform or other raised structure to a height of not less than 125 mm; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a solid or mesh panel that extends from the floor of the platform or other raised structure to a height of not less than 450 mm, if the tools or other objects are piled to a height that a toe board will not prevent them from falling.

Subsection.Text: If the installation of a toe board is not practical on a scaffold, a stage or any other raised structure, all tools or other objects that could fall on a person must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: tied in a manner that will protect any persons beneath, if the tools or other objects fall; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: placed in a way that they will be caught by a safety net positioned so as to protect from injury any persons on or below the raised area, if the tools or the other objects fall.

Section.Text: The design, construction and installation of a safety net referred to in subsection 12(9), paragraphs 16(5)(b) and 147(1)(b) must meet the standards set out in ANSI/ASSE Standard A10.11-1989 (R1998), Safety Requirements for Safety Nets.

Subsection.Text: As far as practicable, the working surface used by an employee must be kept free of grease, oil or any other slippery substance and of any material or object that may create a hazard to an employee.
Every work area used by an employee must be kept free of accumulations of ice and snow while the area is in use.
This Part applies to crew accommodation.
The following provisions do not apply in respect of a day vessel:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: sections 20 to 40;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: sections 42 to 45; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: sections 51 to 54.

Subsection.Text: The following provisions do not apply in respect of a vessel of less than 200 gross tonnage, engaged in inland voyages or constructed before the day on which the MLC 2006 comes into force in Canada:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: sections 20 to 23;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subsection 24(2);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: sections 26 to 29;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: subsections 30(2) to (4);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: section 31;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: sections 33 to 35;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: sections 38 to 40;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: sections 42 and 43;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: sections 48 to 55;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: subsection 56(2); and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: subsection 56(4).

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of this section, a vessel is deemed constructed on the earlier of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which its keel is laid, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which construction identifiable with a specific vessel begins.

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative, as defined in section 2 of the Canada Shipping Act, 2001, of a Canadian vessel that is carrying 15 or more crew members must ensure that there is separate hospital accommodation on board the vessel if it is engaged on one of the following types of voyage of more than three days duration:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an unlimited voyage;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a near coastal voyage, Class 1; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an international voyage, other than an inland voyage.

Section.Text: The employer must ensure that there is adequate headroom in all crew accommodation and the minimum headroom in all crew accommodation where full and free movement is necessary must be at least 203 cm.

Subsection.Text: The sleeping quarters, mess rooms, recreation rooms, passageways in the crew accommodation space and their external bulkheads must be adequately insulated to prevent condensation or overheating.

If there is a possibility of resulting heat effects in adjoining accommodation or passageways, steam and hot-water service pipes, machinery casings and boundary bulkheads of galleys and other spaces where heat is produced must be adequately insulated.

Section.Text: External bulkheads and any part of a bulkhead that separates sleeping quarters from cargo and machinery spaces, galleys, storerooms, drying rooms or communal sanitary areas must be constructed of steel or other materials approved under the Canada Shipping Act, 2001 and be watertight and airtight.

Subsection.Text: Materials used to construct internal bulkheads, panelling, sheeting, floors and joinings must comply with the Hull Construction Regulations or the Crew Accommodation Regulations.
The bulkhead surfaces and deckheads must be constructed so that they can be easily cleaned and maintained in a sanitary condition.
The bulkhead surfaces and deckheads in sleeping quarters and mess rooms must be light in colour with a durable non-toxic finish.

The deck covering in all crew accommodation must be of material and construction approved under the Canada Shipping Act, 2001 and provide a non-slip surface impervious to moisture that is capable of being easily cleaned and maintained in a sanitary condition.
If deck covering is made of composite materials, any joints must be profiled to avoid crevices.
The deck covering in all crew accommodation must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be kept free of grease, oil or any other slippery substance and any material or object that may create a hazard to an employee; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have sufficient drainage.

Subsection.Text: As far as practicable, electric light with two independent sources of electricity must be provided in the crew accommodation.
If it is not possible to provide two independent sources of electricity for lighting, additional lighting must be provided by installed lamps or lighting apparatus for emergency use.
Subject to subsections (3) and (4), sleeping quarters must be located above the load line amidships or aft.
Sleeping quarters must not open directly into cargo and machinery spaces, galleys, storerooms, drying rooms or communal sanitary areas.

In passenger vessels and in special purpose vessels if arrangements are made for lighting and ventilation, sleeping quarters may be located below the load line, but in no case are they to be located beneath working passageways.

If the size, type or intended service of the vessel renders any other location impractical, sleeping quarters may be located in the fore part of the vessel, but in no case are they to be located forward of the collision bulkhead.
As far as practicable, the sleeping quarters must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be of adequate size and be properly equipped so as to ensure reasonable comfort and to facilitate tidiness; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with a sanitary facility, taking into consideration the size of the vessel, the activity in which it is to be engaged and its layout.

Subsection.Text: Except on passenger vessels, all sleeping quarters must be provided with a wash basin with hot and cold running fresh water from taps that are clearly marked to indicate whether the water supply is hot or cold, unless the room is equipped with a sanitary facility containing a wash basin.
As far as practicable, the minimum floor area per person for sleeping quarters of employees with officer duties must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on vessels other than passenger vessels and special purpose vessels,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: 7.5 m2 in vessels of less than 3,000 gross tonnage,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: 8.5 m2 in vessels of at least 3,000 but less than 10,000 gross tonnage, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: 10 m2 in vessels of at least 10,000 gross tonnage or more; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on passenger vessels and special purpose vessels,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: 7.5 m2 for junior officers, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: 8.5 m2 for senior officers.

Subsection.Text: In this section, junior officers means officers at the operational level and senior officers means officers at the management level.

As far as practicable, the master, the chief mate, the chief engineer and the second engineer are to be provided with, in addition to their sleeping quarters, an adjoining sitting room, day room or equivalent additional space.
As far as practicable, individual sleeping quarters must be provided for each employee.
In individual sleeping quarters for employees, the minimum floor area must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 4.5 m2 in vessels of less than 3,000 gross tonnage;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 5.5 m2 in vessels of at least 3,000 but less than 10,000 gross tonnage; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: 7 m2 in vessels of at least 10,000 gross tonnage or more.

Subsection.Text: If it is not possible to provide individual sleeping quarters to employees,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: separate sleeping quarters must be provided for men and women;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an officer must not share their sleeping quarters with more than one other person;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: as far as practicable, watchkeepers who are on different watches must not share their sleeping quarters; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: as far as practicable, employees working during the day must not share their sleeping quarters with watchkeepers.

Subsection.Text: As far as practicable, on passenger vessels and special purpose vessels, the floor area of sleeping quarters for employees not performing officer duties must not be less than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 7.5 m2 in rooms accommodating two persons;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 11.5 m2 in rooms accommodating three persons; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: 14.5 m2 in rooms accommodating four persons.

Subsection.Text: As far as practicable, in vessels of less than 3,000 gross tonnage, other than passenger vessels and special purpose vessels, no more than two persons are to share their sleeping quarters, and the floor area of that room must not be less than 7 m2.
On special purpose vessels, sleeping quarters may accommodate more than four persons in one room and the floor area of that room must not be less than 3.6 m2 per person.

Section.Text: Space occupied by berths, lockers, chests of drawers and seats must be included in the measurement of the floor area while small or irregularly shaped spaces, which do not add effectively to the space available for free movement and cannot be used for installing furniture, must be excluded.
A separate berth must be provided for each employee and arranged so that the berth is as comfortable as possible for the employee and any partner who may accompany the employee.
The minimum inner dimensions of a berth must be 198 cm by 80 cm.

Subsection.Text: The framework and the lee-board, if any, of a berth must be constructed from material that is hard, smooth and impervious to moisture and not likely to corrode or to harbour vermin.
If tubular frames are used for the construction of berths, the tubes must be completely sealed and without perforations.
No more than one berth is to be placed over another.
A berth must not be placed over another if a sidelight is located above a berth that is placed along the ship’s side.
If one berth is placed over another,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the lower berth must be at least 30 cm above the floor;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the upper berth must be placed approximately midway between the bottom of the lower berth and the lower side of the deckhead beams; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a dust-proof bottom must be fitted beneath the bottom mattress or spring bottom of the upper berth.

Subsection.Text: Each berth must be fitted with a mattress with a cushioning bottom or a combined cushioning mattress that includes a spring bottom or a spring mattress.
The employer must provide a set of clean bedding to be used on board a vessel during the employee’s service.
The bedding set must, at a minimum, consist of the following items of appropriate size for the berth:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one pillow;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one pillow case;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: two flat bedsheets; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: one blanket.

Subsection.Text: The employee must return the bedding set on completion of service on board a vessel.

Section.Text: In sleeping quarters, an electric reading lamp must be installed at the head of each berth.
Sleeping quarters must be equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a table or desk, which may be of the fixed, drop-leaf or slide-out type;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: comfortable seating accommodation;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a mirror, small cabinets for toiletries, a book rack and one coat hook per occupant; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: curtains or an equivalent covering for the portholes.

Subsection.Text: Each occupant must be provided with a clothes locker with a capacity of at least 475 l and a drawer or equivalent space with a capacity of at least 56 l, unless the drawer is incorporated into the clothes locker, in which case the combined minimum volume must be 500 l.
The clothes locker must be fitted with a shelf and be capable of being locked.

Section.Text: The furniture must be constructed of a smooth, hard material that is not prone to warping or corrosion.

Subsection.Text: When an employee is required to eat on board a vessel there must be, as far as practicable, a galley or dining area equipped with, at a minimum, the following items:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a hot plate or a range;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a microwave oven;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a toaster;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a refrigerator or a cooler;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: dish washing facilities; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: pots, pans, strainers, dishes and utensils, in sufficient number to accommodate the greatest number of employees likely to use them at any one time.

Subsection.Text: Every dining area provided by the employer must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: of sufficient size to allow individual seating and table space for each employee using the area;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provided with non-combustible covered receptacles for the disposal of food waste or garbage; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: separated from any place where a hazardous substance may contaminate food, dishes or utensils.

Section.Text: Mess rooms must be located as close as practicable to the galley and as far as practicable from the sleeping quarters and any place where a hazardous substance may contaminate food, dishes or utensils.
On vessels, other than passenger vessels, the floor area of mess rooms for employees must not be less than 1.5 m2 per person of the planned seating capacity.

Subsection.Text: In all vessels, mess rooms must be equipped with tables and seats sufficient to accommodate the number of employees likely to use them at any one time.
The tops of tables and seats must be made of a moisture-resistant material.

Section.Text: The following things must be available at all times in mess rooms when employees are on board a vessel:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a conveniently located refrigerator of a capacity sufficient for the number of employees using the mess room;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: facilities for hot beverages and cool water;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: non-combustible covered receptacles for the disposal of food waste or garbage; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: adequate lockers for mess utensils and suitable facilities for washing utensils, if pantries are not accessible from mess rooms.

Section.Text: All employees, on vessels normally engaged on voyages of more than four hours’ duration, must have convenient access to sanitary facilities.

Subsection.Text: As far as practicable, separate sanitary facilities must be provided for men and women.

If separate sanitary facilities are provided, each sanitary facility must be equipped with a door that is self-closing and clearly marked to indicate the sex of the employees for whom the facility is provided.
If male and female employees use the same sanitary facilities, the doors to the facilities must be fitted with an inside locking device.

Section.Text: Sanitary facilities for vessels engaged in voyages of more than four hours must be equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a minimum of one toilet, one wash basin and one tub or shower, provided at a convenient location for every group of not more than six persons who do not have a personal toilet, wash basin and tub or shower;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: fresh water running from taps that are clearly marked to indicate whether the water supply is hot or cold;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: wash basins made of vitreous china, vitreous enamelled iron or other material having a smooth and impervious surface that is not likely to crack, flake or corrode; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: toilets that have

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a bowl of vitreous china or other suitable material,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a hinged seat,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a trap constructed in a manner that facilitates cleaning,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: an adequate flush of water, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: a soil pipe of adequate size that is constructed in a manner that facilitates cleaning and minimizes the risk of obstruction.

Section.Text: Sanitary facilities must be located

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: not more than one deck above or below each work place;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: close to the sleeping quarters of the employee for whom the sanitary facility is provided; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: as far as practicable, within easy access of the navigating bridge and the machinery space or the engine room control centre.

Section.Text: A sanitary facility must meet the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it must be completely enclosed by bulkheads that are non-transparent from the outside;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it must not be directly accessible from a dining area or galley or sleeping quarters, unless it is a part of that sleeping quarters’ private accommodation;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if practicable, it must be directly accessible from a passageway; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if it contains more than one water closet, each water closet must be enclosed in a separate compartment fitted with a door and an inside locking device.

Section.Text: If an employee is required to live on board a vessel, the employer must provide a laundry facility or other arrangement so that laundry can be done on a regular basis.
If employees are required to live on board a vessel, they must be given access to a specified open deck when they are off-duty.
A vessel of more than 3000 gross tonnage must have a ship’s office for use by employees of the deck and engine departments.
If an employee is required to live on board a vessel, a recreational facility must be furnished at a minimum with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a bookcase that contains vocational and other books, the inventory of which must be adequate for the duration of the voyage and changed at reasonable intervals together with a facility for reading and writing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a radio capable of receiving broadcast on bands such as AM/FM/SW; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a television set equipped with electronic equipment capable of showing films, the inventory of which must be adequate for the duration of the voyage and changed at reasonable intervals.

Subsection.Text: An employer must provide hospital accommodation on board a vessel in accordance with the Marine Personnel Regulations.
The hospital accommodation must be easy to access and suitable to accommodate and promptly care for persons in need of medical care.
The vessel’s master must ensure that the accommodation is used exclusively for medical purposes.

As far as practicable, sanitary facilities containing a minimum of one toilet, one wash basin and one tub or shower must be provided for the exclusive use of the occupants of the hospital accommodation, either as part of the accommodation or in close proximity to it.
The system of ventilation for sleeping quarters and mess rooms must be controlled so as to maintain the air in a satisfactory condition and to ensure sufficient air circulation at all times.
All sanitary spaces must have ventilation to the open air, independent of any other part of the accommodation.
Each personal service room and galley must be ventilated to provide at least two changes of air per hour

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by mechanical means, if the room is normally used by 10 or more employees at any one time; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by mechanical means or natural ventilation through a window or similar opening, if the room is used by fewer than 10 employees and

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the window or opening is located on an outside wall of the room, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: not less than 0.2 m2 of unobstructed ventilation is provided for each of the employees who normally use the room at any one time.

Subsection.Text: If an employer provides ventilation by mechanical means, the amount of air provided for a type of room set out in column 1 of the table to this subsection must be no less than that set out in column 2.

Subsection.Text: If an employer provides for the ventilation of a galley or a canteen by mechanical means, the rate of change of air must be at least 9 l/s for each employee who is normally employed in the galley at any one time or for each employee who uses the canteen at any one time, as the case may be.

Section.Text: In sleeping quarters and galleys, the temperature, measured one metre above the deck in the centre of the room or galley, must be maintained at a level of not less than 18°C and, if practicable, not more than 29°C.

Subsection.Text: All vessels, except those regularly engaged in trade where temperate climatic conditions do not require it, must be equipped with air conditioning for crew accommodation, for any separate radio room and for any centralized machinery control room.
Air conditioning systems must be designed to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: maintain the air at a satisfactory temperature and relative humidity as compared to outside air conditions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure a sufficient number of air changes in all air-conditioned spaces;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: take account of the particular characteristics of operations at sea;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: not produce excessive noises or vibrations; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: facilitate cleaning and disinfection in order to prevent or control the spread of disease.

Subsection.Text: In all vessels in which a heating system is required, steam must not be used as a medium for heat transmission within crew accommodation areas.

The heating system must be capable of maintaining the temperature in crew accommodations at a satisfactory level under normal conditions of weather and climate likely to be met within the trade in which the vessel is engaged.
Radiators and other heating apparatus must be placed and, where necessary, shielded so as to avoid risk of fire, danger or discomfort to the occupants.

If weather and climate conditions so require, power for the operation of the air conditioning, heating and other aids to ventilation must be available at all times when employees are living or working on board the vessel.

Section.Text: In this Part, communicable disease has the same meaning as in section 2 of the Quarantine Act.

Subsection.Text: Every employer must maintain each personal service room, galley and pantry used by employees in a clean and sanitary condition.
Each personal service room and galley must be cleaned at least once every day that it is used.
If a vessel is in operation, an inspection must be made once a week of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the supplies of food and water on the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all spaces and equipment used for the storage and handling of food; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the galley and equipment used for the preparation and service of food.

Subsection.Text: A record of each inspection, made in accordance with subsection (1), must be kept by the employer on the vessel for a period of three years after the day on which the inspection is made.

Section.Text: All cleaning and sweeping that may cause dusty or unsanitary conditions must be carried out in a manner that will prevent the contamination of the air by dust or other substances injurious to health.

If an interior deck on a vessel is normally wet and employees on the vessel do not use non-slip waterproof footwear, the deck must be covered with a dry false floor or platform or treated with a non-slip product or substance.
Each container that is used for solid or liquid waste in a work place must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with a tight-fitting cover;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be constructed so that it can be easily cleaned and maintained in a sanitary condition;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be leak-proof; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if there may be internal pressure in the container, be designed so that the pressure is relieved by controlled ventilation.

Subsection.Text: As far as practicable, each enclosed part of a work place, personal service room, galley or pantry must be constructed, equipped and maintained in a manner that will prevent the entry of vermin.

If vermin have entered any enclosed part of a work place, personal service room, galley or pantry, the employer must immediately take all steps necessary to eliminate the vermin and prevent their re-entry.

Section.Text: A person must not use a personal service room for the purpose of storing equipment or supplies unless a closet fitted with a door is provided in that room for that purpose.

Subsection.Text: All reasonable steps must be taken to ensure that personal service rooms are kept mold and mycosis free.
In each personal service room and galley, the decks, partitions and bulkheads must be constructed so that they can be easily cleaned and maintained in a sanitary condition.

Section.Text: The deck and lower 150 mm of any partition or bulkhead that is in contact with the deck in a galley or sanitary facility must be watertight and impervious to moisture.
In every sanitary facility, the employer must provide

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: toilet paper on a holder or in a dispenser in each toilet compartment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: powdered or liquid soap or other sanitizing agent in a dispenser at each wash basin or between adjoining wash basins;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: sufficient sanitary hand drying facilities to serve the number of employees using the sanitary facility;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a non-combustible container for used disposable towels if disposable towels are provided; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a covered container lined with a plastic bag for the disposal of sanitary napkins, if the sanitary facility is provided for the use of female employees.

Section.Text: In every personal service room that contains a wash basin, the employer must provide

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: powdered or liquid soap or other sanitizing agent in a dispenser at each wash basin or between adjoining wash basins;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: sufficient sanitary hand drying facilities to serve the number of employees using the personal service room; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a non-combustible container for the disposal of used towels if towels are provided.

Subsection.Text: Every shower must be provided with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: hot and cold water; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: soap or other sanitizing agent.

Subsection.Text: If duck-boards are used in showers, they must not be made of wood.
Every employer must ensure that employees are provided with potable water for drinking, personal washing and food preparation.
The potable water must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be in sufficient quantity to meet the purposes set out in subsection (1); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meet the quality guidelines set out in the most recent edition of Guidelines for Canadian Drinking Water Quality, prepared by the Federal-Provincial-Territorial Committee on Drinking Water and published by the Department of Health.

Subsection.Text: Potable water for drinking must be available at all times for the use of every employee working on the vessel.
Every employer must develop a potable water management program that sets out the testing procedures and frequency and the measures to be taken to prevent contamination.
The potable water management program must be made readily available for inspection.

Every vessel of 300 gross tonnage or more that is not a day vessel must have on board a supply of water that is available for all wash basins, tubs and showers and is sufficient to provide at least 68 l of water for each employee on the vessel for each day that the employee spends on that vessel.
A day vessel must have on board at least 22.7 l of water for each employee on the vessel for each day that the employee spends on that vessel.

Section.Text: If it is necessary to transport water for drinking, personal washing or food preparation, only sanitary portable water containers must be used.
If a portable storage container for drinking water is used,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the container must be securely closed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the container must be used only for storing potable water;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the container must not be stored in a sanitary facility; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the water must be drawn from the container by

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a tap,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a ladle used only for the purpose of drawing water from the container, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: any other means that precludes the contamination of the water.

Section.Text: Any ice that is added to drinking water or used for the contact refrigeration of foodstuffs must be made from potable water, and stored and handled so as to prevent contamination.
If drinking water is supplied by a drinking fountain,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the fountain must meet the standards set out in the Air-Conditioning and Refrigeration Institute (ARI) of the United States ARI 1010-2002, Self-Contained, Mechanically-Refrigerated Drinking-Water Coolers; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the fountain must not be installed in a sanitary facility.

Heading.TitleText: Preparation, Handling, Storage and Serving of Food

Section.Text: Each food handler must be trained and instructed in food handling practices that prevent the contamination of food.
A person who is suffering from a communicable disease must not must work as a food handler.

If food is served in a work place, the employer must adopt and implement the most recent edition of the Food Safety Code of Practice, published by the Canadian Restaurant and Foodservices Association.

Subsection.Text: Foods that require refrigeration to prevent them from becoming hazardous to health must be maintained at a temperature of 4°C or lower.
Foods that require freezing to prevent them from becoming hazardous to health must be maintained at a temperature of –18°C or lower.

Section.Text: All equipment and utensils that come into contact with food must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: designed to be easily cleaned;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: smooth, free from cracks, crevices, pitting or unnecessary indentations; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: cleaned and stored to maintain their surfaces in a sanitary condition.

Section.Text: No person must eat, prepare or store food in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a place where a hazardous substance may contaminate food, dishes or utensils;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a personal service room that contains a water closet, urinal, tub or shower; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any other place where food is likely to be contaminated.

Section.Text: Food waste or garbage must not be stored in a galley.
Garbage must be held in leak-proof, non-absorptive, easily cleaned containers with tight-fitting covers.
Dry food waste and garbage must be removed or incinerated.

Subsection.Text: Food waste and garbage containers must be kept covered and the food waste and garbage removed as frequently as is necessary to prevent unsanitary conditions.
Food waste and garbage containers must be cleaned and disinfected in an area separate from the galley each time they are emptied.

Heading.Label: PART 5
Heading.TitleText: Safe Occupancy of the Work Place

Section.Text: In this Part work place violence constitutes any action, conduct, threat or gesture of a person towards an employee in their work place that can reasonably be expected to cause harm, injury or illness to that employee.
Fire protection equipment must be installed, inspected and maintained on board every vessel in accordance with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Vessel Fire Safety Regulations, in the case of vessels in respect of which those Regulations apply, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Fire Detection and Extinguishing Equipment Regulations, as they read immediately before being repealed, in any other case.

Section.Text: Emergency evacuation equipment must be installed, inspected and maintained on board every vessel in accordance with the Life Saving Equipment Regulations.

Subsection.Text: Every employer must prepare emergency procedures, including evacuation procedures, in accordance with the Boat and Fire Drill and Means of Exit Regulations.
Notices that set out the details of the emergency procedures must be posted in conspicuous places that are accessible to every employee in the work place.

Section.Text: Every employee must be trained and instructed in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the procedures to be followed by an employee in the event of an emergency; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the location, use and operation of fire protection equipment and emergency equipment provided by the employer.

Subsection.Text: A visual inspection of every vessel must be carried out by a qualified person at least once every six months and must include an inspection of all fire escapes, exits and stairways and fire protection equipment on board the vessel in order to ensure that they are in serviceable condition and ready for use at all times.

A record of each inspection must be dated and signed by the person who carried out the inspection and kept by the employer on board the vessel for a period of two years after the day on which it is signed.

Heading.Label: DIVISION 2
Heading.TitleText: Violence Prevention in the Work Place

Section.Text: The employer must carry out its obligations under this Division in consultation with and with the participation of the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative.

The employer must develop and post at a conspicuous place accessible to all employees a work place violence prevention policy setting out, among other things, the following obligations of the employer:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to provide a safe, healthy and violence-free work place;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to dedicate sufficient attention, resources and time to address factors that contribute to work place violence including, but not limited to, bullying, teasing, and abusive and other aggressive behaviour and to prevent and protect against it;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to communicate to its employees information in its possession about factors contributing to work place violence; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: to assist employees who have been exposed to work place violence.

Heading.TitleText: Identification of Factors that Contribute to Work Place Violence

Section.Text: The employer must identify all factors that contribute to work place violence, by taking into account, at a minimum, the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: its experience in dealing with those factors and with work place violence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the experience of other employers in dealing with those factors and with violence in similar work places;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the location and circumstances in which the work activities take place;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the employees’ reports of work place violence or the risk of work place violence;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: its investigation of work place violence or the risk of work place violence; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the measures that are already in place to prevent and protect against work place violence.

Subsection.Text: The employer must assess the potential for work place violence by using the factors identified under section 98 and taking into account, at a minimum, the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the work activities;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the working conditions;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the design of the work activities and surrounding environment;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the frequency of situations that present a risk of work place violence;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the severity of the adverse consequences to an employee exposed to a risk of work place violence;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the observations and recommendations of the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative, and of the employees; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the measures that are already in place to prevent and protect against work place violence.

Subsection.Text: The employer, when consulting with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative, must not disclose information whose disclosure is prohibited by law or could reasonably be expected to threaten the safety of individuals.

Once an assessment of the potential for work place violence has been carried out under section 99, the employer must develop and implement systematic controls to eliminate or minimize work place violence or the risk of work place violence to the extent reasonably practicable.
The controls must be developed and implemented as soon as practicable, but not later than 90 days after the day on which the risk of work place violence has been assessed.

Once controls referred to in subsection (1) are implemented, the employer must establish procedures for appropriate follow-up maintenance and corrective measures, including measures to promptly respond to unforeseen risks of work place violence.
Any controls established to eliminate or minimize work place violence must not create or increase the risk of work place violence.

Heading.TitleText: Work Place Violence Prevention Measures Review

Subsection.Text: The employer must review the effectiveness of the work place violence prevention measures set out in sections 97 to 100 at least once every three years and update them whenever there is a change that compromises the effectiveness of those measures.
The review must include consideration of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: work place conditions and work locations and activities;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: work place inspection reports;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the employees’ reports and the employer’s records of investigations into work place violence or the risk of work place violence;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: work place health and safety evaluations;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: data on work place violence or the risk of work place violence in the employees’ work place or in similar work places;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the observations of the policy committee, or if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: other relevant information.

Subsection.Text: The employer must keep, for a period of three years, a paper or electronic record of findings following the review of the work place violence prevention measures and make it readily available for examination by the Minister.

Heading.TitleText: Procedures in Response to Work Place Violence

Subsection.Text: The employer must develop in writing and implement emergency notification procedures to summon assistance if immediate assistance is required, in response to work place violence.

The employer must ensure that employees are made aware of the emergency notification procedures applicable to them and that the text of those procedures is posted at a conspicuous location accessible to those employees.

In the development and implementation of emergency notification procedures, the employer’s decision whether or not to notify the police must take into account the nature of the work place violence and the concerns of employees who experienced the work place violence.

If the police are investigating a violent occurrence, the work place committee or the health and safety representative must be notified of their investigation, unless notification is prohibited by law.
The employer must develop and implement measures to assist employees who have experienced work place violence.
In this section, competent person means a person who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is impartial and is seen by the parties to be impartial;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has knowledge, training and experience in issues relating to work place violence; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has knowledge of relevant legislation.

Subsection.Text: If an employer becomes aware of work place violence or alleged work place violence, the employer must try to resolve the matter with the employee as soon as feasible.

If the matter is unresolved, the employer must appoint a competent person to investigate the work place violence and provide that person with any relevant information whose disclosure is not prohibited by law and that would not reveal the identity of persons involved without their consent.
The competent person must investigate the work place violence and at the completion of the investigation provide the employer with a written report containing their conclusions and recommendations.
The employer must, on completion of the investigation into the work place violence,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: keep a record of the report from the competent person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide the work place committee or the health and safety representative, as the case may be, with the report of the competent person, providing information whose disclosure is not prohibited by law and that would not reveal the identity of persons involved without their consent; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: adapt or implement, as the case may be, controls referred to in subsection 100(1) to prevent a recurrence of the work place violence.

Subsection.Text: Subsections (3) to (5) do not apply if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the work place violence was caused by a person other than an employee;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it is reasonable to consider that engaging in the violent situation is a normal condition of employment; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the employer has effective procedures and controls in place, involving employees, to address work place violence.

Subsection.Text: The employer must provide information, instruction and training in the factors that contribute to work place violence that are appropriate to the work place of each employee exposed to work place violence or a risk of work place violence.
The employer must provide information, instruction and training

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: before assigning to an employee any new activity for which a risk of work place violence has been identified; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when new information on work place violence becomes available.

Subsection.Text: The information, instruction and training must include the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the nature and extent of work place violence and how employees may be exposed to it;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the communication system established by the employer to inform employees about work place violence;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: information on what constitutes work place violence and on the means of identifying the factors that contribute to work place violence;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the work place violence prevention measures set out in sections 97 to 100; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the employer’s procedures for reporting on work place violence or the risk of work place violence.

Subsection.Text: At least once every three years and in either of the following circumstances, the employer must review and update, if necessary, the information, instruction and training provided:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when there is a change in respect of the risk of work place violence; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when new information on the risk of work place violence becomes available.

Subsection.Text: The employer must keep signed records, in paper or electronic form, on the information, instruction and training that each employee is provided with for a period of two years after the day on which an employee ceases to perform an activity that has a risk of work place violence associated with it.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: detached work place means a work place away from a vessel where employees normally employed on the vessel are engaged in work related to the operation of the vessel for extended periods of time. (lieu de travail isolé)
first aid room means a room used exclusively for first aid or medical purposes. (salle de premiers soins)
health unit means a consultation and treatment facility that is in the charge of a person who is a registered nurse under the laws of any province. (service de santé)
medical facility means a medical clinic or the office of a physician. (installation médicale)
medicine chest means a container in which an assortment of medicines is stored. (pharmacie de bord)

Section.Text: Every employer must ensure that a vessel engaged on a voyage has at least one employee holding a training certificate that meets the requirements of paragraph 207(3)(g) of the Marine Personnel Regulations, unless an exemption in respect of the vessel has been granted under the Canada Shipping Act, 2001.

Subsection.Text: A vessel must carry a complete and up-to-date list of radio stations from which medical advice can be obtained.
If a vessel is equipped with a system of satellite communication, it must carry a complete and up-to-date list of coast earth stations from which medical advice can be obtained.

Section.Text: Employees with responsibility for medical care or first aid must be instructed by the employer in the use of the ship’s medical guide and in the medical section of the most recent edition of the International Code of Signals so that they can understand the type of information needed by the advising doctor and the advice received.
Every employer must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: establish written instructions that provide for the prompt rendering of first aid to an employee for any injury, disabling injury or illness;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: make a copy of the instructions readily available for examination by employees; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if a cargo which is classified dangerous has not been included in the most recent edition of the Medical First Aid Guide for Use in Accidents Involving Dangerous Goods, make available to the employees the necessary information on the nature of the substances, the risks involved, the necessary personal protection equipment required, the relevant medical procedures and specific antidotes.

Section.Text: If an employee sustains an injury or becomes aware that they have a disabling injury or illness, the employee must, if possible, report immediately for first aid to a person who holds a first aid certificate.

Subsection.Text: The employer must ensure that on board every vessel

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: there is at least one person who holds a first aid certificate and who can immediately render first aid to employees who are injured or ill; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for every work place at which employees are working on live electrical equipment, there is at least one employee who has, in the 12 months before the performance of the work on the electrical equipment, successfully completed a course in cardiopulmonary resuscitation given by an approved organization.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply to shore-based employees for whom a first aid room, a health unit or a medical facility is provided on shore.

Section.Text: Emergency medical and dental care while employees are on board a vessel or landed in a foreign port must be provided free of charge.
Measures must be taken to ensure that employees have access, when in port, to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: outpatient treatment for injury and illness;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: hospitalization when necessary; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: dental treatment.

Heading.TitleText: First Aid Kit, Medicine Chest, Medical Equipment and Medical Guide

Subsection.Text: The employer must provide and maintain for a work place set out in column 1 of Table 1 to this section the type of first aid kit set out in column 2 and a medical guide.

The first aid kit and its contents, as well as the medical equipment and medical guide carried on board a vessel, must be properly maintained and inspected at regular intervals of not more than 12 months, by a qualified person to ensure that supplies and equipment are properly stored and labelled with directions for their use and their expiry date, that all equipment functions as required and that all supplies have not reached or exceeded their expiry dates and are not set to expire before to the next scheduled inspection date.
Every first aid kit must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: accessible when an employee is on board the vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: clearly identified by a conspicuous sign.

Subsection.Text: A first aid kit must contain the supplies and equipment set out in column 1 of Table 2 to this section in the applicable quantities set out in column 2.
