Subsection.Text: Every vessel that is engaged on an unlimited voyage, a near coastal voyage, Class 1 or an international voyage of more than three days’ duration, other than an inland voyage, must carry a medicine chest, medical equipment and the most recent edition of the International Medical Guide for Ships, published by the World Health Organization.

The medicine chest and its contents, as well as the medical equipment and the International Medical Guide for Ships must be properly maintained and inspected at regular intervals of not more than 12 months by a qualified person to ensure that medicines are properly stored and labelled with directions for their use and their expiry date, that all equipment functions as required and that all supplies and medicines have not reached or exceeded their expiry dates and are not set to expire before the next scheduled inspection date.
Every medicine chest must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: accessible when an employee is on board the vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: clearly identified by a conspicuous sign.

Subsection.Text: The employer must provide and maintain a medicine chest with supplies and medicine in accordance with the recommendations of the most recent version of the International Medical Guide for Ships, taking into consideration the particulars of the intended voyage.

Section.Text: If a hazard of skin or eye injury from a hazardous substance exists in a work place, shower facilities to wash the skin and eye wash facilities to irrigate the eyes must be provided for immediate use by employees, or if it is not practicable to do so, portable equipment must be provided.
Before assigning employees to a detached work place, the employer must provide them with the following for that work place:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: suitable means of transporting an injured employee to the vessel, a medical facility or a hospital;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person who holds a first aid certificate to accompany an injured employee and to render first aid in transit if required; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a means of communication between the detached work place and the vessel.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), an employer must post and keep posted in a conspicuous place accessible to every employee on board a vessel

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: information regarding first aid to be rendered for any injury, disabling injury or illness; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: information regarding the location of medicine chests.

Subsection.Text: At a detached work place, the information referred to in subsection (1) must be kept inside the first aid kit referred to in section 114.
If an injured or ill employee reports for first aid to a person in accordance with section 110 or if a person who holds a first aid certificate renders first aid to an employee, the person must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: enter in a first aid record the following information:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the date and time of the reporting of the injury, disabling injury or illness,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the full name of the injured or ill employee,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the date, time and location of the occurrence of the injury, disabling injury or illness,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a brief description of the injury, disabling injury or illness,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: a brief description of the first aid rendered, if any, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: a brief description of arrangements made for the treatment or transportation of the injured or ill employee; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: sign the first aid record beneath the information entered in accordance with paragraph (a).

Subsection.Text: The employer must keep a first aid record for a period of two years after the day on which information is entered in it.

Section.Text: The employer must, in consultation with and with the participation of the policy committee, or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative, develop, implement and monitor a program for the prevention of hazards, including ergonomics-related hazards, in the work place that is appropriate to the size of the work place and the nature of the hazards and that includes the following components:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an implementation plan;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a hazard identification and assessment methodology;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: hazard identification and assessment;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: preventive measures;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: employee education; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a program evaluation.

Subsection.Text: The employer must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: develop an implementation plan that specifies the time frame for each phase of the development and implementation of the prevention program;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: monitor the progress of the implementation of the preventive measures; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: review the time frame of the implementation plan regularly and, if necessary, revise it.

Subsection.Text: In implementing the prevention program, the employer must ensure, as far as practicable, that ergonomics-related hazards are identified and assessed and that they are eliminated or reduced, as required by subsection 124(1), and that any person assigned to identify and assess ergonomics-related hazards has the necessary training and instructions.

The employer must develop a hazard identification and assessment methodology, including an identification and assessment methodology for ergonomics-related hazards, taking into account the following documents and information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any hazardous occurrence investigation reports;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: first aid records and minor injury records;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: work place health protection programs;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: results of any work place inspections;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any employee reports made under paragraph 126(1)(g) or (h) of the Act or under section 275;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: any government or employer reports, studies and tests concerning the health and safety of employees;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: any reports made under the Safety and Health Committees and Representatives Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the record of hazardous substances; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: any other relevant information, including ergonomics-related information.

Subsection.Text: The hazard identification and assessment methodology must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the steps and time frame for identifying and assessing the hazards;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the keeping of a record of the hazards; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a time frame for reviewing and, if necessary, revising the methodology.

Subsection.Text: The employer must identify and assess the hazards in the work place, including ergonomics-related hazards, in accordance with the methodology developed under section 122 and taking into account

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the hazard;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of ergonomics-related hazards, all ergonomics-related factors, such as

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the physical demands of the work activities, the work environment, the work procedures, the organization of the work and the circumstances in which the work activities are performed, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the characteristics of materials, goods, persons, animals, things and workspaces and the features of tools and equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the employees’ level of exposure to the hazard;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the frequency and duration of the employees’ exposure to the hazard;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the effects, real or apprehended, of the exposure on the health and safety of the employee;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the preventive measures in place to address the hazard;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: any employee reports made under paragraphs 126(1)(g) or (h) of the Act or under section 275; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: any other relevant information.

Subsection.Text: The employer must assess a cargo hold in accordance with subsection (1) to determine if it is a confined space and each time there is a change in conditions that may create a hazard.

The employer must, in order to address identified and assessed hazards, including ergonomics-related hazards, take preventive measures to address the assessed hazard in the following order of priority:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the elimination of the hazard, including by way of engineering controls which may involve mechanical aids, equipment design or redesign that take into account the physical attributes of the employee;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the reduction of the hazard, including isolating it;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the provision of personal protection equipment, clothing, devices or materials; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: administrative procedures respecting, among other things, work permits issued under Part 13, the management of hazard exposure and recovery periods and the management of work patterns and methods.

Subsection.Text: As part of the preventive measures, the employer must develop and implement a preventive maintenance program in order to avoid failures that could result in a hazard to employees.
The employer must ensure that any preventive measure must not in itself create a hazard and must take into account the effects on the work place.
The preventive measures must include steps to address

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: newly identified hazards in an expeditious manner; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ergonomics-related hazards that are identified when planning implementation of change to the work environment or to work duties, equipment, practices or processes.

Subsection.Text: The employer must provide each employee with health and safety education, including education relating to ergonomics and it must include the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the hazard prevention program implemented in accordance with this Part to prevent hazards applicable to the employee, including the hazard identification and assessment methodology and the preventive measures taken by the employer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the work place and the hazards associated with it;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the employee’s duty to report under paragraphs 126(1)(g) and (h) of the Act and under section 275; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an overview of the Act and these Regulations.

Subsection.Text: The employer must provide an employee with education

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when new information in respect of a hazard in the work place becomes available to the employer; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shortly before the employee is assigned a new activity or exposed to a new hazard.

Subsection.Text: The employer must review the employee education program, and, if necessary, revise it

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at least once every three years;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when there is a change in conditions in respect of a hazard; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: when new information in respect of a hazard in the work place becomes available to the employer.

Subsection.Text: Each time an employee is provided with education, the employee must acknowledge in writing that they received it and the employer must acknowledge in writing that they provided it.

The employer must keep, in paper or electronic form, records of the education that each employee is provided with for a period of two years after the day on which the employee ceases to be exposed to a hazard.
The employer must evaluate the effectiveness of the hazard prevention program, including its ergonomics-related components, and, if necessary, revise it

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at least once every three years;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when there is a change in conditions in respect of a hazard; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: when new information in respect of a hazard in the work place becomes available to the employer.

Subsection.Text: The evaluation of the effectiveness of the prevention program must be based on the following documents and information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: conditions related to the work place and the activities of the employees;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any work place inspection reports;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any hazardous occurrence investigation reports;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any safety audits;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: first aid records and any injury statistics, including records and statistics relating to ergonomics-related first aid and injuries;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: any observations of the policy and work place committees, or the health and safety representative, on the effectiveness of the prevention program; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: any other relevant information.

Subsection.Text: If a program evaluation has been conducted under section 126, the employer must prepare a program evaluation report.
The employer must keep every program evaluation report for a period of six years after the day on which the report is prepared and make it readily available for examination for that period.

Section.Text: The employer must ensure that all diving operations from a vessel meet the same requirements as those set out in Part XVIII of the Canada Occupational Health and Safety Regulations.
The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: boatswain’s chair means a single-point adjustable suspension scaffold consisting of a seat or sling designed to accommodate one employee in a sitting position. (chaise de gabier)

persons transfer apparatus includes a platform, bucket, landing boom or basket or boatswain’s chair designed specifically for the purpose of transporting, lifting, moving and positioning persons. (appareil de transbordement de personnes)

Section.Text: This Part applies to every persons transfer apparatus used for the purpose of carrying persons on board a vessel, and every safety device attached to that apparatus.

Subsection.Text: Every persons transfer apparatus and every safety device attached to it must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the standards set out in the applicable standard referred to in subsection (2) as far as is reasonably practicable; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be used, operated and maintained in accordance with the standards set out in the applicable standard referred to in subsection (2).

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), the applicable standard for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: elevators, dumbwaiters and escalators is ASME A17.1-2007/CSA B44-07, Safety Code for Elevators and Escalators, and CSA Standard CAN/CSA-B44.1/ASME-A17.5-04, Elevator and Escalator Electrical Equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: manlifts is CSA Standard CAN/CSA-B311-02, Safety Code for Manlifts;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: personnel hoists is CSA Standard CAN/CSA-Z185-M87 (R2006), Safety Code for Personnel Hoists;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: lifts for persons with physical disabilities is CSA Standard CAN/CSA B355-00 (R2005), Lifts for Persons with Physical Disabilities;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: descent control devices is CSA Standard Z259.3-99 (R2004), Descent Control Devices; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: landing booms is the most recent edition of The Seaway Handbook, issued by St. Lawrence Seaway Management Corporation.

Subsection.Text: A persons transfer apparatus on a vessel must not be used or operated in the following circumstances:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: with a load in excess of the load that it was designed and installed to move safely; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when the roll of the vessel is more than the maximum roll for the safe operation of the persons transfer apparatus recommended by the manufacturer.

Subsection.Text: A persons transfer apparatus must not be used or placed in service while any safety device attached to it is inoperative.
A safety device attached to a persons transfer apparatus must not be altered, interfered with or rendered inoperative.
Subsections (2) and (3) do not apply in respect of a persons transfer apparatus or a safety device that is being inspected, tested, repaired or maintained by a qualified person.
A persons transfer apparatus must not be used to transfer freight unless the apparatus is specifically designed for freight and people or if there is an emergency.
Every transfer of a person by means of a persons transfer apparatus must be made only when visibility and environmental conditions are such that the transfer can be made safely.
If a person is transferred by means of a persons transfer apparatus to or from a place on a vessel or to or from a place off a vessel,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person in charge of the transfer operation must be in direct radio contact with the operator of the apparatus; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person to be transferred must

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: be instructed in the safety procedures to be followed by them,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: wear a flotation suit if the conditions warrant, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: must use a life jacket or a personal flotation device unless, if for medical or emergency reasons, it is not practical to wear one.

Subsection.Text: If a person is transferred by a basket to or from a drilling unit or an offshore production facility, the drilling unit or production facility must be equipped with at least two buoyant baskets.
A boatswain’s chair must provide stable and adequate support for the user.

A boatswain’s chair must be suspended from a parapet clamp, cornice hook, thrust-out beam or other solid anchorage having a working load limit that is at least equivalent to that of the suspension system for the boatswain’s chair.

Section.Text: A boatswain’s chair must only be used when visibility and weather conditions permit its safe use.

Subsection.Text: Every persons transfer apparatus must be inspected and found to be in serviceable condition before each use and all ropes, wires or other vital parts that show signs of significant wear must be replaced before the apparatus is used.
Every persons transfer apparatus and every safety device attached to it must be inspected and tested by a qualified person to ascertain that the requirements referred to in section 131 are met

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: before the persons transfer apparatus and any safety device attached to it are placed in service;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: after an alteration to the persons transfer apparatus or any safety device attached to it; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: once every 12 months.

Subsection.Text: A record of each inspection and test made in accordance with subsection (2) must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be made and signed by the qualified person who made the inspection and performed the test;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: include the date of the inspection and test and the identification and location of the persons transfer apparatus and any safety devices that were inspected and tested;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: set out the observations of the qualified person on the safety of the apparatus and any safety device;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be kept by the employer on the vessel on which the persons transfer apparatus is located for a period of two years after the day on which the inspection is signed; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: be made readily available for examination by the operator of the apparatus.

Section.Text: Repair and maintenance of a persons transfer apparatus or a safety device attached to it must be performed by a qualified person appointed by the employer.

Subsection.Text: The employer must ensure that every person granted access to a work place who is exposed to a health or safety hazard uses the protection equipment prescribed by this Part

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if it is not reasonably practicable to eliminate or control a health or safety hazard in a work place within safe limits; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the use of the protection equipment may prevent or reduce injury from that hazard.

Subsection.Text: All protection equipment must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be designed to protect the person from the hazard for which it is provided;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: not in itself create a hazard;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be maintained, inspected and tested by a qualified person; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if necessary to prevent a health hazard, be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition by a qualified person.

Section.Text: If there is a hazard of head injury in a work place, the employer must provide protective headwear that meets the standards set out in CSA Standard CAN/CSA-Z94.1-05, Industrial Protective Headwear - Performance, Selection, Care, and Use.

Subsection.Text: If there is a hazard of a foot injury or electric shock through footwear in a work place, the employer must ensure that every person granted access to that work place uses protective footwear that meets the standards set out in CSA Standard CAN/CSA-Z195-02 (R2008), Protective Footwear.
If there is a hazard of slipping in a work place, non-slip footwear must be used.

Section.Text: If there is a hazard of injury in a work place to the eyes, face, ears or front of the neck, the employer must provide eye or face protectors that meet the standards set out in CSA Standard Z94.3-07, Eye and Face Protectors.

Subsection.Text: If there is a hazard of an airborne hazardous substance or an oxygen-deficient atmosphere in a work place, the employer must provide a respiratory protective device or breathing apparatus that is listed in the most recent version of the NIOSH Certified Equipment List.

A respiratory protective device or breathing apparatus referred to in subsection (1) must be selected, fitted, cared for, used and maintained in accordance with the standards set out in CSA Standard CAN/CSA-Z94.4-02 (R2007), Selection, Care and Use of Respirators.
If air is provided by means of a respiratory protective device or breathing apparatus referred to in subsection (1)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the air must meet the standards set out in clause 15.3 of CSA Standard CAN/CSA-Z180.1-00 (R2005), Compressed Breathing Air and Systems; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the system that supplies air must be constructed, tested, operated and maintained in accordance with the CSA Standard referred to in paragraph (a).

Subsection.Text: If a steel or aluminum self-contained breathing apparatus cylinder has a dent deeper than 1.5 mm and less than 50 mm in major diameter or shows evidence of deep isolated pitting, cracks or splits, the cylinder must be removed from service until it has been shown to be safe for use by means of a hydrostatic test at a pressure equal to one and one-half times the maximum allowable working pressure.

Section.Text: If there is a hazard of injury or disease to or through the skin of a person in a work place, the employer must provide any person granted access to the work place with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a shield or a screen;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a cream or a barrier lotion to protect the skin; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an appropriate body covering.

Subsection.Text: The employer must provide a fall-protection system to every person, other than an employee who is installing or removing a fall-protection system, who is granted access to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an unguarded work area that is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: more than 2.4 m above the nearest permanent safe level,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: above any moving parts of machinery or any other surface or thing that could cause injury to a person on contact, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: above an open hold;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a structure referred to in Part 2 that is more than 3 m above a permanent safe level; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a ladder at a height of more than 2.4 m above the nearest permanent safe level and because of the nature of the work, that person can use only one hand to hold onto the ladder.

Subsection.Text: The components of a fall-protection system must meet the following standards:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: CSA Standard Z259.1-05, Body Belts and Saddles for Work Positioning and Travel Restraint;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: CSA Standard CAN/CSA-Z259.2.1-98 (R2008), Fall Arresters, Vertical Lifelines and Rails;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: CSA Standard CAN/CSA-Z259.2.2-98 (R2009), Self-Retracting Devices for Personal Fall-Arrest Systems;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: CSA Standard Z259.2.3-99 (R2004), Descent Control Devices;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: CSA Standard Z259.10-06, Full Body Harnesses;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: CSA Standard Z259.11-05, Energy Absorbers and Lanyards;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: CSA Standard CAN/CSA-Z259.12-01 (R2006), Connecting Components for Personal Fall Arrest Systems (PFAS);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: CSA Standard Z259.13-04 (R2009), Flexible Horizontal Lifeline Systems; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: CSA Standard Z259.16-04 (R2009), Design of Active Fall-Protection Systems.

Subsection.Text: The anchor of a fall-protection system must be capable of withstanding a force of 17.8 kN.
A fall-protection system that is used to arrest the fall of a person must prevent that person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: from being subjected to a peak fall arrest force of more than 8 kN; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: from falling freely for more than 1.2 m.

Subsection.Text: An employer must train and instruct every employee required to install or remove a fall-protection system in a work place in the procedures to be followed for the installation or removal of the system.

Section.Text: Loose-fitting clothing, long hair, dangling accessories, jewellery or other similar items that are likely to be hazardous to health or safety in a work place must not be worn unless they are tied, covered or otherwise secured so as to prevent the hazard.

If persons granted access to a work place are regularly exposed to the risk of coming into contact with moving vehicles during their work, the employer must ensure that they wear a high-visibility vest or other similar clothing that is readily visible under all conditions of use or that they are protected by a barricade that is readily visible under all conditions of use.

Subsection.Text: If, in a work place, there is a hazard of drowning, as a result of work activities, other than vessel abandonment drills, the employer must provide every person granted access to the work place with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a life jacket or other flotation device that meets the buoyancy standards set out in

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the Canadian General Standards Board (CGSB) Standard CAN/CGSB-65.7-2007, Life Jackets; or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: Regulation 2 of Part 1 to IMO Resolution MSC.81(70), adopted on December 11, 1998 and entitled Revised Recommendation on Testing of Life-Saving Appliances; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a safety net or a fall-protection system.

Subsection.Text: If, in a work place, there is a hazard of drowning,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: emergency equipment must be provided and held in readiness;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a qualified person to operate all the emergency equipment provided must be present and ready to intervene;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if appropriate, a vessel must be provided and held in readiness; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: written emergency procedures, meeting the requirements set out in the regulations made under the Canada Shipping Act, 2001, must be prepared by the employer.

Subsection.Text: A record of all self-contained breathing apparatus provided by the employer must be kept by the employer on the vessel on which the breathing apparatus is located for a period of two years after the day on which the apparatus ceases to be used.
The record must contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the breathing apparatus and the date of its acquisition by the employer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the date and result of each inspection and test of the breathing apparatus;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the date and nature of any maintenance work performed on the breathing apparatus since its acquisition by the employer; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the person who performed the inspection, test or maintenance of the breathing apparatus.

Subsection.Text: An employer must instruct every person granted access to a work place who is to use protection equipment in the use of the equipment.
An employer must train and instruct every employee who uses protection equipment in the use, operation and maintenance of the equipment.
The instruction referred to in subsections (1) and (2) must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: set out in writing; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: kept by the employer and made readily available for examination by every person granted access to the work place.

Subsection.Text: An employee who finds any defect in protection equipment that may render it unsafe for use must report the defect to the employer as soon as possible.
An employer must mark or tag as unsafe and remove from service any protection equipment used by employees that has a defect that may render it unsafe for use.

Section.Text: In this Part, VDT means a visual display terminal.

Subsection.Text: This Part does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel of less than 500 gross tonnage;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the bridge of a vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the exterior deck of a vessel where lighting levels may create a hazard to navigation.

Subsection.Text: Subject to any special arrangements that may be permitted in passenger vessels, sleeping quarters and mess rooms must be illuminated by natural light and provided with adequate artificial light.

Emergency lighting must, in the event of the failure of the main electric lighting, provide sufficient illumination to allow the crew to safely exit from confined spaces and proceed through passageways and stairways to the open deck.
The lighting levels must meet one of the following standards:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ANSI/IES RP-7-01, Lighting Industrial Facilities; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the standard entitled The IESNA Lighting Handbook: Reference and Application, 9th Edition published by the Illuminating Engineering Society of North America (IESNA).

Heading.TitleText: Measurements of Average Levels of Lighting

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Part, the average level of lighting in an area must be determined by taking four or more measurements at different places in the areas set out below and by dividing the total of the results of the measurements by the number of measurements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if work is performed at a level higher than the deck, at the level at which the work is performed; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, 1 m above the deck.

Subsection.Text: If the average level of lighting is measured in a dry provision storage room, it must be measured when the room is empty.
The lighting level measurements must be carried out by a qualified person.
Every vessel must be equipped with an emergency lighting system that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: operates automatically in the event of a failure of the lighting system or if the regular power supply is interrupted;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provides a level of lighting of 50 lx; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is inspected, tested and maintained to the prescribed requirements set out in one of the following regulations:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: Classed Ships Inspection Regulations, 1988,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: Hull Construction Regulations,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: Small Vessel Regulations, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: Towboat Crew Accommodation Regulations.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of the deck or cargo space of a vessel.
The level of lighting at any place in an area must not be less than one third of the average level of lighting prescribed by this Part for the area.
The average level of lighting in a work area set out in column 1 of the table to this subsection must not be less than the level set out in column 2.

Section.Text: Unless otherwise specified, all working, walking and climbing areas must be illuminated to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an average level of 50 lx; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a minimum level of 30 lx at any place in those areas.

Subsection.Text: The average level of lighting at a task position set out in column 1 of the table to this subsection must not be more than the average level set out in column 2.

Provision.Text: Task positions at which data entry and retrieval work are performed intermittently

Subsection.Text: Reflection glare on a VDT screen must be reduced to the point where an employee at a task position is able to read every portion of any text displayed on the screen and see every portion of the visual display on the screen.
If VDT work requires the reading of a document, supplementary lighting must be provided where necessary to give a level of lighting of at least 500 lx on the document.

Section.Text: The following provisions do not apply in respect of vessels constructed before the day on which the MLC 2006 comes into force in Canada:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: section 160; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subsection 161(5).

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: A-weighted sound pressure level means a sound pressure level as determined by a measurement system which includes an A-weighting filter that meets the requirements set out in the International Electrotechnical Commission International Standard IEC 61672-1:2002(E), 1st edition 2002-2005 Electroacoustics – Sound Level Meters. (niveau de pression acoustique pondérée A)
dBA means decibel A-weighted and is a unit of A-weighted sound pressure level. (dBA)

noise exposure level (Lex,8) means 10 times the logarithm to the base 10 of the time integral over any 24-hour period of a squared A-weighted sound pressure divided by 8, the reference sound pressure being 20 µPa. (niveau d’exposition (Lex,8))

sound level meter means an instrument for measuring levels of sound and impulse sound that meets the standards set out in CSA Standard CAN/CSA-Z107.56-06, Procedures for the Measurement of Occupational Noise Exposure. (sonomètre)

sound pressure level means 20 times the logarithm to the base 10 of the ratio of the root mean square pressure of a sound to the reference sound pressure of 20 µPa, expressed in decibels. (niveau de pression acoustique)

Subsection.Text: Accommodation and recreational and catering facilities must be located as far as practicable from the engines, steering gear rooms, deck winches, ventilation, heating and air conditioning equipment and other noisy machinery and apparatus.

Acoustic insulation or other appropriate sound-absorbing materials and self-closing noise-isolating doors for machinery spaces must be used in the construction and finishing of bulkheads, deckheads and decks within the sound-producing spaces.
Engine rooms and other machinery spaces must be provided, wherever practicable, with soundproof centralized control rooms for engine-room personnel.
Working spaces, such as the machine shop, must be insulated, as far as practicable, from the general engine-room noise and measures must be taken to reduce noise in the operation of machinery.
Accommodation or recreational or catering facilities must not be exposed to excessive vibration.
Subject to subsections (2) to (4), the level of sound in a work place must be less than 85 dB.

Subject to subsection (3), if it is not reasonably practicable for an employer to maintain the level of sound in the work place at less than 85 dB, an employee must not be exposed in any 24-hour period

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to a level of sound set out in column 1 of the table to this section for a number of hours that is more than the number set out in column 2; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to any combination of the different levels of sound set out in column 1 of the table to this section, if the number of hours of exposure to each level of sound divided by the maximum number of hours of exposure for that level per 24-hour period set out in column 2 of the table to this section is more than one.

Subsection.Text: An employee must not be exposed to a continuous level of sound in crew accommodation that is more than 75 dB.
If the level of impulse sound in a work place is more than 140 dB, the employer must provide every employee entering the work place with a hearing protector that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meets the standards set out in CSA Standard CAN/CSA-Z94.2-02 (R2007), Hearing Protection Devices — Performance, Selection, Care and Use; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: reduces the peak level of impulse sound reaching the employee’s ears to 140 dB or less.

Subsection.Text: Unless otherwise specified, the limits for noise levels for working and crew accommodations must comply with the ILO international guidelines on exposure levels, including those in the ILO code of practice, entitled Ambient factors in the workplace, 2001, and, if applicable, the specific protection recommended by the IMO, and with any subsequent amending and supplementary instruments for acceptable noise levels on board vessels.
A copy of the documents in English and in French referred to in subsection (5) must be kept on board the vessel and be made available to employees.

Subsection.Text: If it is not reasonably practicable for an employer to maintain the exposure of an employee to a level of sound at or below the levels referred to in section 161, the employer must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: appoint a qualified person to carry out an investigation of the degree of exposure;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: notify the work place committee or the health and safety representative of the investigation and of the name of the person appointed to carry out the investigation; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: provide every employee entering the work place with a hearing protector that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: meets the standards set out in CSA Standard CAN/CSA-Z94.2-02 (R2007), Hearing Protection Devices, Performance, Selection, Care and Use, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: reduces the level of sound reaching the employee’s ears to less than 85 dB.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), the measurement of the A-weighted sound pressure level in a work place must be performed instantaneously, in normal working conditions, using the slow response setting of a sound level meter.
During the investigation referred to in subsection (1), the following matters must be considered:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the sources of sound in the work place;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the A-weighted sound pressure levels to which the employee is likely to be exposed and the duration of that exposure;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the methods being used to reduce the exposure;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: whether the exposure of the employee is likely to be more than the limits prescribed by section 161; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: whether the employee is likely to be exposed to a noise exposure level (Lex,8) equal to or greater than 85 dBA.

Subsection.Text: On completion of the investigation and after consultation with the work place committee or the health and safety representative, as the case may be, the person appointed to carry out the investigation must set out in a written report signed and dated by the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: observations respecting the matters considered under subsection (3);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: recommendations respecting the measures that are to be taken in order to comply with section 161; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: recommendations respecting the use of hearing protectors by employees who are exposed to a noise exposure level (Lex,8) equal to or greater than 85 dBA and not greater than 87 dBA.

Subsection.Text: The report must be kept by the employer at the work place where it applies for a period of 10 years after the day on which the report is submitted.
If it is stated in the report that employees are likely to be exposed to a noise exposure level (Lex,8) equal to or greater than 85 dBA, the employer must, without delay,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: post and keep posted a copy of the report in a conspicuous place in the work place where it applies; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide the employees with written information describing the hazards associated with exposure to high levels of sound.

Section.Text: The levels of sound must be measured by using the slow exponential-time-averaging characteristic and the A-weighting characteristic of a sound level meter.
In a work place where the level of sound is 85 dB or more, the employer must post signs warning persons entering the work place

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that there is a hazardous level of sound in the work place;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, of the maximum number of hours of exposure determined under subsection 161(2); and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, of the requirement to wear a hearing protector.

Section.Text: The employer must assess the following types of work to determine if the work presents a hazard that is capable of causing death or serious injury:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: work on live electrical equipment that cannot be isolated or grounded;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: work on electrical equipment that is capable of becoming live during that work;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: hot work, as defined in section 189;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: work that requires exposure to hazardous substances beyond the limits referred to in subsection 255(1); and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any other work that may present a hazard that is capable of causing death or serious injury.

Section.Text: The employer is required to issue a written work permit to a qualified person before the commencement of the following types of work:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: work that requires entry into confined spaces; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any other work that has been assessed under section 165 as presenting a hazard that is capable of causing death or serious injury.

Section.Text: The work permit must contain the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the person who issues the permit;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the person to whom it is issued;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the periods during which the permit is valid;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the type of work to be performed and its location; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: assessment of conditions related to the hazard of performing the work, and instructions arising from those conditions, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the work procedures to be followed,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the identification of equipment that is to be locked out in accordance with CSA Standard CAN/CSA-Z460-05, Control of Hazardous Energy - Lockout and Other Methods,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of any safety tests to be performed before the work is performed, during the performance of the work and following the completion of the work,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the specification of the particulars of the tags or signs to be used, if any,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the specification of the protection equipment to be used, if any,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of an emergency, the procedures to be followed,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the specific space, work or electrical equipment to which the instructions apply, and

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: the identification of any other work permit that may affect the emergency or work procedures to be followed.

Subsection.Text: The work permit must be signed by the employer and the terms, rights and obligations explained to and signed by the person to whom that permit is issued.

The work permit must be made readily available for examination by employees for the period in which the work is being performed and after that period it must be kept by the employer for a period of two years after the day on which the work is completed, at the place of business nearest to the work place in which the work is completed.
Work authorized under a work permit may be performed only after the equipment has been locked out in accordance with the standard referred to in subparagraph 167(e)(ii).

Section.Text: A person must not enter a confined space without having been issued a work permit under section 166.
Before authorizing a person to enter a confined space, the employer must ensure that all the requirements of this Part are met.

Subsection.Text: Before authorizing a person to enter a confined space on a vessel, the employer must appoint a marine chemist or other qualified person to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: carry out an assessment of any hazardous substance in the confined space; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: specify the necessary tests to determine whether employees are likely to be exposed to the hazard.

Subsection.Text: The assessment must, at a minimum, verify that the following requirements are respected:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the concentration of any chemical agent to which the person is likely to be exposed in the confined space is not more than the value or level referred to in subsection 255(1) or the percentage referred to in subsection 255(5);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the concentration of airborne hazardous substances, other than chemical agents, in the confined space is not hazardous to the health or safety of the person;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the percentage of oxygen in the atmosphere in the confined space is not less than 19.5 per cent by volume and not more than 23 per cent by volume at normal atmospheric pressure and in any case the partial pressure of oxygen is not less than 148 mm Hg; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the value, level or percentage referred to in paragraphs (a) to (c) can be maintained during the period of proposed occupancy of the confined space by the person.

Subsection.Text: The qualified person must, in a written report signed by that person, set out the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the vessel on which the confined space is located;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the confined space on the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a record of the results of the assessment made in accordance with subsection (2);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the type, model, serial number and date of last calibration of any instrument used in the assessment process;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an evaluation of the hazards of the confined space;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: if the employer has established procedures to be followed by a person entering into, exiting from or performing work in the confined space, which of those procedures are applicable;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: if the employer has not established procedures referred to in paragraph (f), the procedures to be followed by the person referred to in that paragraph;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the protection equipment referred to in Part 10 that is to be used by every person granted access to the confined space; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: if the employer has established emergency procedures to be followed in the event of an accident or other emergency in or near the confined space, which of the procedures are to be followed, including immediate evacuation of the confined space when

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an alarm is activated, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: there is any significant change in the value, level or percentage referred to in subsection (2).

Section.Text: The written report referred to in subsection 171(3) must be kept by the employer on the vessel on which the confined space is located for a period of two years after the day on which the marine chemist or other qualified person signs the report.

Heading.TitleText: Additional Requirements for the Issuance of a Work Permit

Subsection.Text: In addition to the requirements set out in section 168, before an employer issues a work permit under section 166, the employer must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: obtain a written report referred to in subsection 171(3) from a qualified person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that any liquid in which a person may drown or any free-flowing solid in which a person may become entrapped has been removed from the confined space;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the entry of any liquid, free-flowing solid or hazardous substance into the confined space has been prevented by a secure means of disconnection or the fitting of blank flanges;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that all electrical equipment and mechanical equipment that presents a hazard to a person entering into, exiting from or performing work in the confined space has been disconnected from its power source and locked out in accordance with the standard referred to in subparagraph 167(e)(ii);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the opening for entry into and exit from the confined space is sufficient in size to allow safe passage of a person who is using protection equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: establish an entry control system.

Subsection.Text: The written report referred to in subsection 171(3) and any procedures identified in that report must be explained to a person who is about to enter into the confined space and that person must sign a dated copy of the report indicating that they have read the report and that the report and the procedures were explained to them.

If conditions in the confined space or the nature of the work to be performed in the confined space are such that any of paragraphs 171(2)(a) to (c) or (1)(b) to (e) cannot be complied with, the employer must comply with the requirements of sections 123 and 124 and must at a minimum ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a qualified person is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in attendance outside the confined space,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in communication with the person inside the confined space, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: provided with a suitable alarm device for summoning assistance;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: each person granted access to the confined space must wear a safety harness that is securely attached to a lifeline that is attached to a secure anchor outside the confined space and is controlled by the qualified person;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: two or more employees, which may include the qualified person, are in the immediate vicinity of the confined space to assist in the event of an accident or other emergency; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: one of the employees referred to in paragraph (c) is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: trained in the emergency procedures referred to in paragraph 172(3)(i),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the holder of a first aid certificate, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: provided with the protection equipment referred to in paragraph 172(3)(h) and any emergency equipment required by the procedures established by the employer under paragraph 172(3)(i).

Subsection.Text: Before a confined space is sealed, the person in charge of the area surrounding the confined space must ascertain that no person is inside the confined space.
If a hazardous substance may be produced in a confined space by the work to be performed,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the confined space must be ventilated in accordance with subsection (2); or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: each person granted access to the confined space must use a respiratory protective device or breathing apparatus referred to in section 142.

Subsection.Text: If an airborne hazardous substance or oxygen in the atmosphere in a confined space is maintained at the value, level or percentage referred to in subsection 172(2) by the use of ventilation equipment, a person may only be granted access to the confined space if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the ventilation equipment is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: equipped with an alarm that will, if the equipment fails, be activated automatically and be audible or visible to any person in the confined space, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: monitored by an employee who is in constant attendance at the equipment and in communication with any person in the confined space; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the event of failure of the ventilation equipment, sufficient time will be available for the person to escape from the confined space before one of the following occurs:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: their exposure to or the concentration of a hazardous substance in the confined space is more than the value, level or percentage prescribed in paragraph 172(2)(a) or (b), and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the percentage of oxygen in the atmosphere ceases to meet the requirements of paragraph 172(2)(c).

Subsection.Text: The employee referred to in subparagraph (2)(a)(ii) must activate an alarm in the event of faulty operation of the ventilation equipment.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: control device means a device that will safely disconnect electrical equipment from its source of energy. (dispositif de commande)
direct supervision means on-site, in-view observation and guidance by a qualified person while an employee performs an assigned task. (supervision immédiate)
guarantor means a person who gives a guarantee of isolation. (garant)

guarded means in respect of electrical equipment, covered, shielded, fenced, enclosed or otherwise protected by means of suitable covers or casing, barriers, guardrails, screens, mats or platforms to remove the possibility of dangerous contact or approach by persons or objects. (protégé)
person in charge means a qualified person who supervises employees performing work on or a live test of isolated electrical equipment. (responsable)

Subsection.Text: All testing or work performed on electrical equipment must be performed by a person in charge or an employee under the direct supervision of a person in charge.
Before authorizing a person to test or perform work on electrical equipment, the employer must ensure that a work permit referred to in section 166 has been obtained.
If there is a possibility that the person in charge or the employee may receive a hazardous electrical shock during the performance of their testing or work,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person in charge or the employee must use insulated protection equipment and tools that will protect them from injury; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the employee must be trained and instructed in the use of the insulated protection equipment and tools.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (5), if an employee is working on or near electrical equipment that is live or may become live, the electrical equipment must be guarded.

If it is not practicable for the electrical equipment to be guarded, the employer must take measures to protect the employee from injury by insulating the equipment from the employee or the employee from ground.

If an employee is working on or near live electrical equipment and, because of the nature of the work or the condition or location of the work place, it is necessary for the safety of the employee that the work be observed by a person not engaged in the work, the employer must appoint a safety watcher

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to warn all employees in the work place of the hazard; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to ensure that all safety precautions and procedures are complied with.

Subsection.Text: Safety watchers must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: informed of their duties as safety watchers and of the hazard involved in the work;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: trained and instructed in the procedures to follow in the event of an emergency;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: authorized to stop immediately any part of the work that they consider dangerous; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: free of any other duties that might interfere with their duties as safety watchers.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), employers may appoint themselves as safety watchers.

Section.Text: If an employee is working on or in connection with electrical equipment, that employee and every other person who is so working, including every safety watcher, must be fully informed by the employer with respect to the safe coordination of their work.

Subsection.Text: Every control device must be designed and located so as to permit quick and safe operation at all times.
The path of access to every electrical switch, control device or meter must be free from obstruction.

If an electrical switch or other control device controlling the supply of electrical energy to electrical equipment is operated only by a person authorized to do so by the employer, the switch or control device must be fitted with a locking device that only the authorized person can activate.
Control switches for all electrically operated machinery must be clearly marked to indicate the switch positions.

Section.Text: Defective electrical equipment must be disconnected from its power source by a means other than the control switch and notices must be placed on the equipment and at the control switch to indicate that the equipment is defective.

Subsection.Text: Electrical fuses must be of the correct ampere rating and fault capacity rating for the circuit in which they are installed.
An employee must not replace missing or burnt-out fuses unless authorized to do so by a person in charge.
Power supply cables for portable electrical equipment must be placed clear of areas used for vehicles unless the cables are protected by guards.
A three-wire power supply cable on electrical equipment or appliances must not be altered or changed for the purpose of connecting the equipment or appliances to a two-wire power supply.

Section.Text: Grounded electrical equipment and appliances must be used only when connected to a matching grounded electrical outlet receptacle.

Heading.TitleText: Additional Requirement for the Issuance of a Work Permit

Section.Text: In addition to the requirements set out in section 168, before an employer issues a work permit for electrical equipment under section 166, the employer must provide a guarantee of isolation in respect of each source of electrical energy.

Heading.TitleText: Guarantees of Isolation of Electrical Equipment

Subsection.Text: An employee must not give or receive a guarantee of isolation for electrical equipment unless they are authorized in writing by their employer to give or receive a guarantee of isolation.
No more than one employee is to give a guarantee of isolation for a piece of electrical equipment for a given period.
Before an employer issues a work permit, the person in charge must receive from the guarantor

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a written guarantee of isolation; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if owing to an emergency it is not practicable for the person in charge to receive a written guarantee of isolation, a non-written guarantee of isolation.

Subsection.Text: The written guarantee of isolation referred to in paragraph (3)(a) must be signed by the guarantor and by the person in charge and must contain the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date and hour when the guarantee of isolation is given to the person in charge;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the date and hour when the electrical equipment will become isolated;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the date and hour when the isolation will be terminated, if known;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the procedures by which isolation is assured;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the guarantor and the person in charge; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a statement as to whether live tests are to be performed.

Subsection.Text: If a non-written guarantee of isolation referred to in paragraph (3)(b) is given, a written record of the guarantee must, as soon as possible be made by the guarantor and signed by the person in charge.
A written record must contain the information referred to in subsection (4).
Every written guarantee of isolation and every written record must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: kept by the person in charge and made readily available for examination by the employee performing the work or live test until the work or live test is completed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: given to the employer when the work or live test is completed; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: kept by the employer for a period of one year after the completion of the work or live test at his place of business nearest to the work place in which the electrical equipment is located.

Subsection.Text: If a written guarantee of isolation or a written record of an oral guarantee of isolation is given to a person in charge and the person in charge is replaced at the work place by another person in charge before the guarantee has terminated, the other person in charge must sign the written guarantee of isolation or written record of the oral guarantee of isolation.

Before an employee gives a guarantee of isolation for electrical equipment that obtains all or any portion of its electrical energy from a source that is not under the employee’s direct control, the employee must obtain a guarantee of isolation in respect of the source from the person who is in direct control of the source and is authorized to give the guarantee in respect of that source.
An employee must not give a guarantee of isolation for the performance of a live test on isolated electrical equipment unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any other guarantee of isolation given in respect of the electrical equipment for any part of the period for which the guarantee of isolation is given is terminated;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every person to whom the other guarantee of isolation referred to in paragraph (a) was given has been informed of its termination; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any live test to be performed on the electrical equipment will not be hazardous to the health or safety of the person performing the live test.

Subsection.Text: Every person performing a live test must warn all persons who, during or as a result of the test, are likely to be exposed to a hazard.

Heading.TitleText: Termination of the Guarantee of Isolation

Subsection.Text: Every person in charge must, when working on a live test or when a live test of isolated electrical equipment is completed,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: inform the guarantor of it; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: make and sign a record in writing containing the date and hour when they so informed the guarantor and the name of the guarantor.

Subsection.Text: On receipt of the information referred to in subsection (1), the guarantor must make and sign a record in writing containing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date and hour when the work or live test was completed; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the person in charge.

Subsection.Text: The records referred to in subsections (1) and (2) must be kept by the employer for a period of one year after the day on which they are signed at the employer’s place of business nearest to the work place in which the electrical equipment is located.
An employee must not attach a safety ground to electrical equipment unless they have tested the electrical equipment and have established that it is isolated.
Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of electrical equipment that is grounded by means of a grounding switch that is an integral part of the equipment.
Subject to subsection (4), work may be performed on any electrical equipment, only if the equipment is connected to a common grounding network, in an area in which is located

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a grounding bus;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a station grounding network;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a neutral conductor;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: temporary phase grounding; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a metal structure.

Subsection.Text: If, after the connections are made, a safety ground is required to ensure the safety of an employee working on the electrical equipment, the safety ground must be connected to the common grounding network.

Every conducting part of a safety ground on isolated electrical equipment must have sufficient current carrying capacity to conduct the maximum current that is likely to be carried on any part of the equipment for the time that is necessary to permit operation of any device that is installed on the electrical equipment so that, in the event of a short circuit or other electrical current overload, the electrical equipment is automatically disconnected from its source of electrical energy.
A safety ground must not be attached to or disconnected from isolated electrical equipment except in accordance with the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the safety ground must, to the extent that is practicable, be attached to the pole, structure, apparatus or other thing to which the electrical equipment is attached;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all isolated conductors, neutral conductors and non-insulated surfaces of the electrical equipment must be short-circuited, electrically bonded together and attached by a safety ground to a point of safety grounding in a manner that establishes equal voltage on all surfaces that can be touched by persons who work on the electrical equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the safety ground must be attached by means of mechanical clamps that are tightened securely and are in direct contact with bare metal;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the safety ground must be secured so that none of its parts can accidentally make contact with any live electrical equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the safety ground must be attached and disconnected using insulated protection equipment and tools;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the safety ground must, before it is attached to isolated electrical equipment, be attached to a point of safety grounding; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the safety ground must, before it is disconnected from the point of safety grounding, be removed from the isolated electrical equipment in a manner that the employee avoids contact with all live conductors.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (6), a point of safety grounding means a grounding bus, a station grounding network, a neutral conductor, a metal structure or an aerial ground.

Section.Text: In this Part, hot work means any work where flame is used or a source of ignition may be produced.
If hot work is to be performed,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a qualified person must be assigned to patrol the working area and the adjoining areas and maintain a fire protection watch of the area for the duration of the work and, if necessary, for a period of 30 minutes after the work is completed; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a sufficient number of fire extinguishers shall be provided in the working area and the adjoining areas.

Section.Text: Hot work must not be performed in a working area where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: flammable gas, vapour or dust may be present in the atmosphere, unless the area has been freed of gas, tested by a marine chemist or other qualified person, and found to be safe for that work to be performed in the area; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an explosive or flammable substance may be present in the working area, unless a marine chemist or other qualified person has ensured that adequate protection exists to permit that work to be safely performed in the area.

Subsection.Text: Electrical welding equipment cables and gas welding or burning equipment cylinders and pipes must be placed clear of areas used for vehicles unless adequate protection for the cables, cylinders and pipes is provided.
Gas cylinders of welding and burning equipment must be placed securely in an upright position when in use.

Section.Text: Before equipment used for hot work is left unattended, the person in charge of the working area must ensure that the equipment is in a safe condition.
If a hazardous substance may be produced in a working area as a result of hot work

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the working area must be well ventilated; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any person in the working area must wear a respiratory protective device.

Subsection.Text: The concentration of any chemical agent to which a person is likely to be exposed in a working area must not be more than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the value referred to in subsection 255(1); or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the percentage referred to in subsection 255(5).

Subsection.Text: The concentration in a working area of airborne hazardous substances, other than chemical agents, must not be hazardous to the health or safety of the person in the area.

Section.Text: The percentage of oxygen in the atmosphere in a working area must not be less than 19.5 per cent or more than 23 per cent by volume at normal atmospheric pressure and in no case is the partial pressure of oxygen to be less than 148 mm Hg.

Subsection.Text: If ventilation equipment is used to maintain the concentration of an airborne hazardous substance below or at the value or percentage referred to in section 195 or the percentage of oxygen in the air of a confined space within the limits referred to in section 196, the employer is prohibited from granting any person access to the working area, unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the ventilation equipment is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: equipped with an alarm that will, if the equipment fails, be activated automatically and be audible or visible to any person in the working area, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: monitored by an employee who is in constant attendance at the equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the event of a failure of the ventilation equipment, sufficient time will be available for a person to escape from the working area before one of the following occurs:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: that person’s exposure to or the concentration of a hazardous substance in the working area is more than the value or percentage prescribed in section 195, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the percentage of oxygen in the atmosphere ceases to meet the requirements of section 196.

Subsection.Text: The employee referred to in subparagraph (1)(a)(ii) must activate an alarm in the event of faulty operation of the ventilation equipment.

Section.Text: This Part does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a heating boiler that has a wetted heating surface of 3 m2 or less;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a pressure vessel that has a capacity of 40 l or less;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a pressure vessel that is installed for use at a pressure of one atmosphere of pressure or less;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a pressure vessel that has an internal diameter of 152 mm or less;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a pressure vessel that has an internal diameter of 610 mm or less and that is used to store hot water;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a pressure vessel that has an internal diameter of 610 mm or less connected to a water pumping system and that contains compressed air which serves as a cushion;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a hydropneumatic tank that has an internal diameter of 610 mm or less; or

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a refrigeration plant that has a capacity of 18 kW or less.

Section.Text: An employer must ensure that every boiler, pressure vessel and pressure piping system used in a work place must, to the extent reasonably practicable, meets the requirements set out in the Marine Machinery Regulations.
An employer must ensure that a qualified person, charged with the operation of a boiler, is in attendance and readily available at all times while the boiler is in operation.
The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: explosive-actuated fastening tool means a tool that, by means of an explosive force, propels or discharges a fastener for the purpose of impinging it on, affixing it to or causing it to penetrate another object or material. (pistolet de scellement à cartouches explosives)
fire hazard area means an area that contains or is likely to contain an explosive or flammable concentration of a hazardous substance. (endroit présentant un risque d’incendie)

Section.Text: This Part applies to machines, tools and guards.

Heading.TitleText: Design, Construction and Operation of Tools

Subsection.Text: The exterior surface of any tool used by an employee in a fire hazard area must be made of non-sparking material.
All portable electric tools used by employees must meet the CSA Standard CAN/CSA-C22.2 NO. 71.1-M89 (R2004), Portable Electric Tools.
All portable electric tools used by employees must be grounded except when the tools

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are powered by a self-contained battery;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have a protective system of double insulation; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: are used in a location where reliable grounding cannot be obtained if the tools are supplied from a double insulated portable ground fault circuit interrupter of the class A type that meets the standards set out in CSA Standard CAN/CSA-C22.2 NO. 144-M91 (R2006), Ground Fault Circuit Interrupters.

Subsection.Text: All portable electric tools used by employees in a fire hazard area must be marked as appropriate for use or designed for use in a fire hazard area.
If an air hose is connected to a portable air-powered tool used by an employee, a restraining device must be attached

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to all hose connections; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if an employee may be injured by the tool falling, to the tool.

Subsection.Text: All explosive-actuated fastening tools used by employees must meet and be operated in accordance with the standards set out in CSA Standard Z166-1975, Explosive Actuated Fastening Tools.
An employee must not operate an explosive-actuated fastening tool unless authorized to do so by their employer.
All chain saws used by employees must meet the standards set out in CSA Standard CAN/CSA-Z62.1-03 (R2008), Chain Saws.
If an employee finds any defect in a tool or machine that may render it unsafe for use, the employee must report the defect to the employer as soon as possible.
An employer must mark or tag as unsafe and remove from service any tool or machine used by employees that has a defect that may render it unsafe for use.
Every employee must be trained and instructed by a qualified person in the safe and proper inspection, maintenance and use of all tools and machines that they are required to use.

An employer must keep a manual of operating instructions for each type of portable electric tool, portable air-powered tool, explosive-actuated fastening tool and machine used by employees and that manual must be made readily available for examination by employees who are required to use the tool or machine to which the manual applies.

Every machine that has exposed moving, rotating, electrically charged or hot parts or that processes, transports or handles material that constitutes a hazard to an employee must be equipped with a machine guard that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prevents the employee or any part of their body from coming into contact with the parts or material;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prevents access by the employee to the area of exposure or to the material or parts that constitute a hazard during the operation of the machine; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: makes the machine inoperative if the employee or any part of their clothing is in or near a part of the machine that is likely to cause injury.

Subsection.Text: To the extent that is reasonably practicable, a machine guard referred to in subsection (1) must not be removable.
A machine guard must be constructed, installed and maintained so that it meets the requirements of subsection (1).
Equipment used in the mechanical transmission of power must meet the requirements set out in ANSI Standard ANSI/AMT B15.1-2000 (R2008), Safety Standard for Mechanical Power Transmission Apparatus.

Heading.TitleText: Use, Operation, Repair and Maintenance of Machines
